title: A new method to measure single cell chromatin accessibility
description: Measuring chromatin accessibility at single cell resolution for large numbers of samples is cost-prohibitive and laborious, and suffers from batch-effects. We developed a new, cost-effective and versatile method, 'sci-ATAC-seq3', that allows us to profile up to 1 million cells and 24 different samples within one experiment. We use this method to generate single cell chromatin accessibility profiles from 59 human tissue samples. From the resulting dataset, we can nominate key TFs for the major cell lineages in the human body, explore their mode of action, and identify cell types involved in heritable diseases.

title: What is a 'cell type'? Thoughts on an updated definition
description: Our systems of classification both reflect and direct our thinking. In this forward looking perspective, we inspect different possible approaches to classifying cell types. We advocate for a data-driven, tree-based nomenclature and provide a thought experiment on how it might be derived.
